column1: Will the US fully evacuate or lose control of its embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, before 1 December 2021?
column6: ['Security and Conflict']
(no change) Fascinating reading:

Comments: On a personal note, I'm quite saddened by this event. I cannot help thinking of the Afghan women and children and what will happen to them. Following consensus. CNN, 08/15/21, 'US completes evacuation of embassy in Afghanistan as flag comes down at diplomatic compound': https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/15/politics/us-embassy-kabul-afghanistan/index.html ABC News, 08/15/21, 'Afghanistan's collapse: Did US intelligence get it wrong?': https://abcnews.go.com/US/afghanistans-collapse-us-intelligence-wrong/story?id=79470553 Clips from ABC News article: 'But numerous U.S. officials tell ABC News that the opposite was true, insisting that key intelligence assessments had consistently informed policymakers that the Taliban could overwhelm the country and take the capital within weeks -- essentially repeating the 1975 fall of Saigon, when helicopters hastily evacuated diplomats from the U.S. embassy's rooftop as the North Vietnamese Army stormed into the South Vietnam capital.'
So the airport (aka the U.S. embassy) is taking fire. This should be fun...
I was so, so wrong. I let positivity get in the way of objective assessment here. Taliban too strong in their counter-offensive and Afghan government was incredibly weak without support.
Like it matters for bier. Its not that i did not expect the embassy to fall, i did not expect it before December 1. Damn, that was friggin fast.

Comments: Funny, we have more US troops positioned to go back in than earlier in the year (2.5k). Marines and the 82nd. A mini 'surge'? What about 'the several hundred U.S. special operations forces working for the CIA on counter-terrorism missions'? Are the Canadian SOF staying after they evacuate their embassy personnel? Are the Brits? Withdrawal of United States troops from Afghanistan (2020–2021): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Withdrawal_of_United_States_troops_from_Afghanistan_(2020%E2%80%932021) Clips from Wikipedia article: 'The Trump administration completed its reduction of forces to 2,500 troops in January 2021, the lowest number of American soldiers in Afghanistan since 2001. As of January 2021, there are more than seven contractors for each U.S. military service member remaining in Afghanistan, amounting to over 18,000 contractors according to figures from U.S. Central Command. In January 2021, then-incoming president Joe Biden's national security adviser Jake Sullivan said that the U.S. would review the peace agreement in order to effectively withdraw its remaining 2,500 soldiers from Afghanistan. Biden supported a full withdrawal in 2014 but it was initially unclear as to whether he would uphold Trump's May 2021 withdrawal deadline. In March 2021, news reports stated that President Biden was potentially considering keeping U.S. forces in Afghanistan until November 2021. On 14 April 2021, Biden announced his intention to withdraw all regular U.S. troops by 11 September 2021, the 20th anniversary of the September 11 attacks and four months after the initially planned 1 May deadline. The day before the announcement, Biden called former U.S. presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama regarding his decision to withdraw. U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said the decision was made in order to focus resources on China and the COVID-19 pandemic. Following withdrawal, the U.S. is reportedly considering options for redeploying troops such as relocating to U.S. Navy vessels, countries in the Middle East, or Central Asian countries like Tajikistan.' On 18 February 2021, Secretary-General of NATO Jens Stoltenberg said that the alliance has not made a decision on how to proceed regarding the withdrawal. Britain is expected to withdraw its remaining 750 Resolute Support Mission troops at the same time as the U.S. According to the plan, NATO troops would also follow the same withdrawal timeline. The U.S. indicated that some troops (the exact number had not yet been decided) will remain in the country to provide diplomatic security, and is unclear what will happen to the several hundred U.S. special operations forces working for the CIA on counter-terrorism missions. New CIA Director William Joseph Burns told the U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee on 14 April 2021 that "[t]here is a significant risk once the U.S. military and the coalition militaries withdraw" but added that the U.S. would retain "a suite of capabilities." The administration of President Biden intends to use a broad array of foreign police tools stretching from military occupation to total abandonment.' CNBC, 08/13/21, 'Canada to send special forces to Afghanistan to close embassy in Kabul, official says': https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/13/canada-to-send-special-forces-to-afghanistan-to-close-kabul-embassy.html BBC News, 08/13/21, 'Afghanistan: UK troops sent to get Britons out as Taliban advances': https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-58195286 About 600 UK troops are to be sent to Afghanistan to assist British nationals to leave, the government has announced. The Fayetteville Observer, 08/12/21, 'Fort Bragg troops to deploy to aid evacuation of Americans from U.S. embassy in Afghanistan': https://www.fayobserver.com/story/news/2021/08/12/fort-bragg-immediate-response-force-rapidly-deploys-middle-east/8114481002/ Clips from Observer article: 'Pentagon officials said Thursday that 3,000 troops were being sent immediately. An additional infantry brigade force of about 3,500 from Fort Bragg will be flown from the United States to the Middle East to stand by in case they are needed. Lt. Col. Joe Buccino, a spokesman for the 18th Airborne Corps at Fort Bragg, confirmed an Immediate Response Force brigade is deploying.' US News & World Report, 07/21/21, 'Number of Private Contractors in Afghanistan Drops Precipitously as Biden Pushes Withdrawal Plan': https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2021-07-21/number-of-private-military-contractors-in-afghanistan-drops-precipitously-as-biden-pushes-withdrawal-plan

The U.S. might keep its embassy in Kabul staffed after a Taliban victory (dumb, but possible), and the Taliban might leave it alone (they seem to be making noises about courting international respectability). But putting faith in the Taliban's possible good intentions does not take into account the possibility of other elements in Afghanistan making an attempt against the embassy. The Taliban, after all, does not necessarily control every warlord militia that claims alignment to it. The embassy could be stormed, and even if U.S. security successfully resisted the attack, the administration might think it prudent to evacuate.

The Taliban has at one point said they'd leave things like embassies alone. However, (1) that isn't a promise and (2) an embassy doesn't have to be threatened directly in order to trigger a full evacuation.

Al Qaeda are doing well, Afghan officials have told me, and there are said to be thousands of loosely affiliated foreign fighters on the battlefield. A "24-7 hype party" is how Rita Katz, head of extremist monitoring group SITE, described al Qaeda social media channels. "In some ways, it feels like the earlier days of the Syria Civil War amid Nusra Front's victories -- except now on a completely different scale, given the Taliban's horrifying momentum," Katz tweeted. History has repeated itself so many times already for Afghans, they are beyond farce now. The enduring question of the next months is whether the West -- faced with the discomfort of the apparently inevitable happening -- decides to change course, if it is not too late.'

Comments: Is Biden following in Nixon's footsteps? Fast-moving events on the ground strongly suggests that the USA is on the same track. Still, Afghanistan is not South Vietnam and decades separate our involvement/history with the two and with significant disasters in-between (Tehran, Desert One, Benghazi) to not have learned some important lessons on risk mitigation, both tactically and strategically. August 31 is still roughly a month away and I expect contingencies are evolving as I write. I believe USSOCOM will play a bigger role in the next 6 months leading the US military effort to slow the Taliban advance on the ground and effect a more stable situation for: 1) the timely withdrawal of conventional US combat forces. 2) to offer combat and morale support for the ANA and Afghan SOF. 3) partner with the CIA for intelligence gathering, up-to-date SITREP in targeted areas, re-establish and maintain status with select militia groups. I see the air war continuing, with mainly unmanned sorties launched from carrier battle groups in the Persian Gulf or bases in Iraq and the Gulf states. For heavy work, bombers from Minot and Barksdale. Affirming forecast. CNN, 08/02/21, 'Taliban take over TV station in strategic city as US airstrikes pound key positions in Afghanistan': https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/02/asia/afghanistan-us-airstrikes-taliban-intl/index.html Washington Post, 06/22/21, 'Militias in Afghanistan’s north are taking up the fight against the Taliban': https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/afghanistan-militias-taliban/2021/06/22/f8fa35c0-d34b-11eb-b39f-05a2d776b1f4_story.html

The situation is continuing to deteriorate; if it gets to the point where the embassy is credibly threatened (by e.g. rockets or mortars, much less ground assault) I suspect the US will evacuate as a precautionary measure. If they wait until the embassy is actually under attack, moving air assets into hostile territory is likely to result in losses that I doubt the US is willing to accept (especially given the Benghazi incident and the political fallout from it).

There's a strong Western media narrative that Taliban victory is imminent. But what's really happening, if you look at hard news stories that report the fighting progress on the ground is that from the Taliban perspective they are taking two steps forward, one step back. They just took a couple districts yesterday: https://tolonews.com/index.php/afghanistan-173440 But on the other hand, the government just retook a district: https://sputniknews.com/asia/202107191083414227-afghan-army-reclaims-capital-of-helmand-province-defense-ministry-says/ Typically if you read the hard news stories, the Taliban takes districts without much of a fight, and then when the government security forces come back to retake the district, the fighting gets intense at times, but the security forces prevail in direct fighting. The war is still very much in the guerrilla phase.

Despite the deteriorating security across Afghanistan, with between 70-85% of the country now directly or indirectly controlled by the Taliban, the US Embassy in Kabul's defense will be of paramount importance to the US government. After 20 years of military involvement in the country, the symbolic costs of leaving or closing the Embassy in a country from which the US has withdrawn in such unilateral and uncoordinated way would be a strong blow to its reputation and Washington will resist this scenario against all odds.

First, this would require for the Taliban to consolidate control over Kabul. Given their territorial gains over the past year (Long War Journal), it is likely (70% probability) that the Taliban will take full control of Afghanistan, including Kabul, by the end of the year. The Taliban have suggested that the group is likely to achieve this through an agreement (on their terms) rather than through military conquest (Politico). Secondly, and under the condition that the Taliban take over, the question is whether the Taliban will accept/tolerate the presence of approx. 650 troops to provide security for the US embassy which is a prerequisite for the embassy to remain (The Hill, Reuters). The Taliban have officially rejected this (BBC). However, the intent and preparations of the US to maintain the presence appears to be high (Politico). This comes also on the backdrop of a potential civilian NATO mission to Afghanistan and the plan for Turkey to take over the management of Kabul airport, including the international hospital which is critical for any foreign presence in the country (Politico) (70%). Taliban could at least temporarily/until the end of the year tolerate the presence as part of a deal with the Afghan government as they consolidate control (20%). Overall, the probability for this to happen is 7% (10% (remainder of 70%+20%) of 70%).
even with the Taliban taking back large parts of the country they won't have the momentum to take Kabul in the winter when they are normally not as active.

Comments: SOF to take point on embassy security. This is unusual. See embassy and surrounding areas under dedicated PSS both for intelligence and intervention. See CIA Kabul station expanding, not contracting. The Washington Post, 07/17/21, 'U.S. diplomats in Afghanistan face daunting, dangerous mission with little military backup': https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/afghanistan-us-embassy-kabul/2021/07/17/6b346812-e63f-11eb-934f-7e6c1927f261_story.html Clips from Post article: 'Despite Biden’s promise to execute a full military withdrawal, about 650 U.S. troops will remain, split between the embassy compound and Kabul’s international airport, which now represents a potential lifeline for foreigners who may need to evacuate in a hurry. Some troops will operate counter-rocket systems known as C-RAMs, which each have Gatling guns that shoot 4,500 rounds per minute.' 'Overseeing the embassy security mission is Rear Adm. Peter Vasely, a two-star Navy SEAL officer who was slated to oversee Special Operations in Afghanistan before Biden called for a withdrawal. “He was available. He had the experience,” Marine Gen. Kenneth “Frank” McKenzie, head of U.S. Central Command, said during a recent visit to Afghanistan. “I know and trust him.” Vasely’s team will operate partly out of the old NATO military headquarters, which will belong to the embassy. Security at the compound is now provided by the State Department, McKenzie said. While Biden’s plan envisions U.S. air power being used in the post-withdrawal period only to target groups such as al-Qaeda and the Islamic State, McKenzie said any threats against the embassy or the Kabul airport could be an exception. If security deteriorates rapidly, the U.S. military trains specialized forces for missions like temporarily seizing an airfield to enable evacuation flights. Or, in drastic circumstances, it could launch a noncombatant evacuation operation as was done in Saigon in 1975 and Mogadishu in 1991.' NPR, 07/12/21, 'With The U.S. Military Gone, The CIA Faces Tough Challenges In Afghanistan': https://www.npr.org/2021/07/12/1014542248/with-the-u-s-military-gone-the-cia-faces-tough-challenges-in-afghanistan

It seems to me very likely (0.85) that this will happen in the next 2-3 years. But highly unlikely in this question's timeframe, b/c the advance on countryside will slow and systematically gaining control of Kabul will be even slower. And for PR-reasons, I expect the US to give strong support in 2021 via Air & Intel in order to not be percieved as being chased out completely while in the process of leaving.
No, It add no thing to Taliban to dominate.

This embassy, like many others, is essentially a theatrical setting rather than a functioning and useful diplomatic post. It has very little practical value, but maintains some symbolic value. It is therefore pointless for the Taliban to take it over so early in the script for this drama. The US won't need to evacuate or abandon it until at least next summer, and maybe never.
Even the Taliban want to seek international legitimacy and wanted an embassy in the US. They would keep the embassy in hopes of reciprocity.

To answer this question it is, I suggest, relevant to look at the geo-political history of Afghanistan. Biden is somewhat disingenuous when he states ‘No nation has ever unified Afghanistan. Empires have gone there and not done it’, suggesting some altruistic actions to unify the tribes of that country. The country could be construed as ungovernable given that as stated by the Middle East Institute, the concentration of power at the local level is so strong, that even the core institutions of the state are undersiege by local interests. The reasons for invasion are therefore geo-political. The British wanted to control Afghanistan to deter the Russians from invading southwards in the 19th Century which lost an army in 1842 but gained a diplomatic solution in 1880, but no control.
“We’re going to engage in a determined diplomacy to pursue peace and a peace agreement that will end this senseless violence,” Biden said.
